signatories.comment:
This is a flagrant violation of free speech and mimics big tech's repression pro-Palestine, the same repression that Peyrin was talking about to begin with. The same tactics that lead to dozens of workers at Google, Amazon, and Microsoft being fired are also being used here because Peyrin dared to speak out for what he believes in.

It's clear UC Berkeley is specifically coming after pro-Palestine speech. STEM studies are too often depoliticized and sanitized, but the truth is that nothing we study and none of the work we do can be free of politics. We need to be having more of the discussions that Peyrin was starting, not less.

As the letter states, technology is not ethically neutral. I did not set out on my intended career path indifferent to the impact I would make in the world. I imagine many Berkeley students arrived here excited to change people's lives for the better through excellent training... and I believe the university (outwardly) encourages that mindset. Why, then, are we expected not to care about the impact of the institution in which we participate?

The suspension of this instructor is a direct violation of his right to free speech. There was harm done on any faculty member during his hunger strike and therefore should be no reason to suspend him.

Ben Hermalin will be catalogued as a Judas of all that education and humanity stand for. I would highly encourage him to resign, stand up for something or sit down!

signatories.comment: As an undergraduate student at UC Berkeley, my professors made political statements in class, particularly after the first election of Donald Trump in 2016, and were not punished or retaliated against. This is clearly retaliation for Peyrin’s activism and speech in support of Palestinians and against the genocide in Gaza, and a first amendment violation. It is all the more disappointing coming from a university that claims to pride itself on its role in the free speech movement.

signatories.roles: UC Alum, Tech Worker, Peyrin was a UGSI for a class I took in Spring 2020 (CS 161)
signatories.comment:
I am a Berkeley EECS alum (Fall 2020) and I currently work in the tech industry. When I think about Berkeley, I think about the way that free speech was touted as an important part of the university's legacy. To throw that legacy - and what makes Berkeley so special - away over ongoing support for a genocide is laughable. 

The EECS major at Berkeley required students to complete an ethics course to graduate because despite the purpotedly "neutral" nature of engineering and computer science, nothing about engineering is neutral. The products we make have real-world impact. However, it seems like the EECS department has forgotten its own teachings - when faced with an actual moral dilemma, they have failed spectacularly.

I am in full support of Peyrin and believe he should be reinstated.

signatories.comment: Peyrin spoke up when he saw wrong when the world around him stood silent. And rather than being on the right side of history UC Berkeley continues to suppress speech while claiming itself to be a bastion of freedom of speech. Peyrin chose bravery and humanity, continuing to stand with oppressed people and our community will stand with him.

signatories.roles: Current Peyrin Student (CS 61B / CS 188), UC Berkeley Undergrad Student, University Undergrad/Grad Student
signatories.comment: It’s so important that educators in cs courses speak to the complicity of tech industries in the Palestinian genocide and violence worldwide. It’s disappointing that the university can claim CDSS is an ethics-oriented cs/ds/stats college while simultaneously silencing and punishing educators who attempt to spread awareness on humanitarian crises happening right now, that students in said college are participating in as they enter the industry as interns for complicit companies. I was a Public Health student first, then decided to double major in Data Science, and it shocked me that fellow CS/DS majors told me they “don’t believe in the genocide”, “don’t believe protest works”, or are interning at Raytheon or something with no consideration to the implications of their career. Does that not alarm the university which goes on to have so many cs/ds students in important positions in the world? Peyrin is a great teacher and example. I took CS61B when he wasn’t teaching and dropped the class, took it again this semester and he helped a lot. I’m sure the university will look back in 50 years and preach the power and importance of students and staff who spoke up against genocide, reaping the benefits of a “progressive” and “free speech” university, but for now prefer to keep their hands bloody for the sake of money. I chose this university for its supposed values and I’m ashamed to be made a fool.

The assertion that students’ seeing the impact of a hunger strike on Peyrin was a violation of Regents Policy 2301 is a dangerous interpretation of that policy. Furthermore, Peyrin’s comments regarding Palestine were made following class. The action against Peyrin seems aimed at limiting free speech and sanctioning a highly visible pro-Palestine voice in campus. Our job as STEM faculty is to encourage our colleagues and students to reckon with the ethical implications of science and technology. I see Peyrin’s actions as doing just that.

UC Berkeley should be ashamed of its treatment of Peyrin. Cal claims to have 7 principles of community, yet the university’s treatment clearly illustrates how it fails to take them seriously, especially Free Speech, Honesty/Integrity, Just Community, and Civility/Respect. Until the university reinstates Peyrin, it will be an embarrassment to claim UC Berkeley as my alma mater.
Peyrin’s voice should be amplified, not silenced. By putting him on unpaid leave, the university is showing how complicit they are in the genocide. Free speech, and free Palestine

UC Berkeley please do better and stop demonizing your fellow staff/students for standing up for what’s right and using his voice for good. Don’t wear your “activism” as a badge of honor only when it benefits you, stick to the truth and speak proudly against ALL injustices. Also your CS department will go to hell without Peyrin let’s be real.

signatories.roles: Current Peyrin Student (CS 61B / CS 188), Former Peyrin Student, EECS/CS Undergrad Student, UC Berkeley Undergrad Student, University Undergrad/Grad Student
signatories.comment:
My first class with Peyrin was CS61B during the Fall of 2023. Throughout that class, he
was nothing but professional. He explained concepts in ways that were easy to
understand and had a very big impact on me in furthering my pursuit of CS. When the
October 7th attacks occurred, as a Jewish student, Peyrin’s class was the class I felt the
most heard and the safest in.

Since CS61B I have taken two other classes from Peyrin and he has been nothing but
an excellent instructor. It is shameful that the university has decided to suspend him
when he is one of the best instructors in the department and has kept his classroom a
safe and productive environment for all students.

Peyrin’s suspension is a disturbing infringement on ethical standards and free speech. By disregarding the complicity and active role of tech and US institutions in an ongoing genocide, UC Berkeley risks eroding its standing as a university grounded in critical inquiry, moral clarity, and academic integrity. This is a profound moral failure and I am deeply disappointed in my Alma Mater, I sincerely hope that UC Berkeley makes the correct decision to reinstate Peyrin and issue a full apology to him and the student body.
